address.streetAddress: Allen Road to Mount Pleasant Road

description: Midtown is a dynamic part of Toronto with some of its most stylish high-rise residences and heritage buildings. The area sees busy shoppers with bag-laden arms balancing lattes in paper cups as they travel from one luxury brand to the next, taking advantage of the proximity of high-end shops. The reflecting pools, jogging trails, and nature treks of the Rosehill Revision are always a hub of outdoor activity, and after a workout from either running or splurging, many take advantage of the spas and massage parlors Midtown has to offer. Away from the bakeries, boutiques, and glamorous old theaters of the district's center, locals use the weekend to embrace the more suburban feel of Midtown's parks, tennis courts, outdoor markets, and the manicured grounds of Casa Loma, while families indulge the area's state-of-the-art playground and learning facilities. Of course, no high-brow district is complete without a healthy counter-culture: Midtown boasts some of the wildest street art and full-wall graffiti of any neighborhood in Toronto.

reviews.title: Pleasant autumn walk
text: For a November afternoon it was balmy (19C) and the Belt Line is a pleasant walk. It's better in summer when the shade of the trees flanking this walk is welcome. In the fall, the direct sun is mostly screened off by the houses on the south side. Still, we enjoyed our one-hour-plus walk, starting from Oriole Parkway almost to Eglinton and then back again.

reviews.title: Quite a challenging trail for running
text: The Beltline as part of a loop that includes the Lower Don trail makes a challenging, but very enjoyable run right from downtown Toronto.  You would hardly know you're right in the heart of Canada's biggest city, but Toronto has many such bits of trails.  The Beltline is an old electric train route. The northerly part is relatively flat, but the bit that connects close to the Don is quite hilly. .

reviews.title: Do not fear the winter
text: The Beltline is not plowed or shoveled in the winter, but the trail is  level and mainly gravel so your footing is not too bad, unless the snow is REALLY deep.  I have been on the Beltline in both summer and winter and like the winter best.  It is normally very quiet, with fewer people. You can access the Beltline from either Mt. Pleasant Road, Avenue Road or Lascelles  Blvd.

reviews.title: Lovely Morning Walk
text: What a great way to spend a morning. Lovely flat walk with trees and lovely people along the way. My husband and I enjoyed a lovely walk from Yonge (Davisville) to Allen Road and then walked along Eglington back to Yonge.Drung the last visit we went along the Beltline Trail to the east. Get walk as well.

reviews.title: A "Train-Spotting" Dog
text: This is a lovely green space running through Midtown Toronto for 9 km. Although it was a dame day, we have walked in worse in the UK, so we ventured out to explore this trail. it is a narrow trail built on an unused rail line, so it is level without hills on most of the trail. You do have to stop for streets and it is sometime difficult to cross, and the trail is interrupted at times by major roads, but is still a great walk in downtown Toronto.

Oh . . .  the train-spotting dog . . . the trail is used by many dog owners, many who do not follow the "Keep your dog on leash" rule, but the little dog we met on the Yonge St. bridge was on a leash, and he was eagerly awaiting the subway train which passes under the bridge. His tail waged as the train approached and he rushed to the other side of the bridge as the train disappeared into the Davisville station. His owner reported that this "Train-spotting" is his favourite activity and does it every day. So if you walk the trail look for the Amazing "Train-Spotting" dog.

reviews.title: Great walk through tree-lined path.
text: It's a great wide path both for walkers & bicycles.  It's tree-lined and therefore lots of shade.  Also a number of branch paths to deviate from the main path. If you are too tired to do the whole length, it's easy to veer off and turn around, coming back on another trail.

reviews.title: Excellent walking trail
text: I used to live in the area and this trail formed one side of my daily hour long walk. I loved it, quiet and peaceful and relatively cool in summer. If you are close by and can access it easily this is a great place to get a little exercise and away from traffic and city stuff for a while.

reviews.title: Great for people and dogs
text: I use this Trail in many ways: as a car-free cycling route, for recreational walks or bike rides with children, to walk the dog, or to jog. It’s wide enough for many people and many modes of transport to co-exist. Lovely year-round, but not maintained in winter, so make sure you’re wearing sturdy boots with plenty of traction. Very dark at night so best to keep an eye on the time.
If you’re cycling, you’ll need off-road tires. Thin city-bike tires won’t survive the bumpy route and many sharp pebbles.

reviews.title: Lovely walk
text: We love this walk. It's a great way to get some exercise in really lovely surroundings. Whole walk is great if you have the time and energy, if not, individual parts are nice too. We particularly like the Mount Pleasant cemetery and popping into the Brickworks area and weekend food market.

reviews.title: Great Escape
text: I love walking down this trail from Yonge to Eglinton when the weather is nice.  It's not maintained in the winter so be careful if there is snow, ice, puddles etc.  In the summer the trail is great because the trees provide a nice canopy.  It's a quiet place in the city to enjoy a bit of nature and get away from the noise.

reviews.title: Nice fall walk
text: I walk this trail regularly when my daughter is at swim lessons. It's a great spot for walking, running, biking or just a casual stroll. Lots of people walking dogs too. It's quite long so you can go quite a ways if you want to.

reviews.title: Nature near the downtown
text: A great path for walking or cycling. You are out in nature with beautiful trees yet just off Young Street. The path folles along Mt Pleasant cemetery. Check out the cemetery as well for an interesting walk.

reviews.title: Very nice Fall ride for the kids!
text: We had a lovely cycle along the Kay Gardiner Beltline Trail to the Mount Pleasant cemetery. Kids loved the trail, very safe and open. And riding around the cemetery, exploring the history and monuments was great for them.

reviews.title: Great trail for running and walking
text: We were fortunate to visit this trail with friends in autumn. It was beautiful in the autumn colors and we went for a LONG walk along the trail. Excellent for runners, which is what our friends do.
Our only regret was that we didn't have more time to come back her more often

reviews.title: Nice easy walk.
text: This trail is the middle section of the Beltline Trail, and was named the Kay Gardner Beltline Park after a local politician. It runs from Mt. Pleasant Road in the east (situated just south of Merton) to the Allen in the west. It is an easy and pleasant walk, especially on a nice spring, summer or fall day. The trail is used by many, many dog walkers, as well as cyclists. If you are lucky enough to live in the area, this is an easily accessible green space.

reviews.title: 15 years of Kay Gardner Beltline trail
text: Today was 15th anniversary of Kay Gardner Beltline trail. This trail was preserved because of tireless efforts of one individual - Kay Gardner who lobbied that decommissioned railroad path will not be sold to adjacent home owners, but to be kept in a public domain. Today we have this beautiful "linear park" in the heart of the city.

reviews.title: Great for getting exercise and fresh air
text: I recently moved from the yonge & st-Clair area. I really miss the belt line. This peaceful trail and walkway was great for getting out and enjoying fresh air.  The yonge st bridge provides a nice view of davisville ttc railyard.  Great for walking your dog or teach your youngster to ride a bike.

reviews.title: Beautiful and relaxing walk
text: The belt line is a great trail for a walk or jog among tall mature trees in the Davisville/Forest Hill area.  Once a railway line servicing outer ring of Toronto in 1890's, this 4.5km pathway has been a favorite spot for folks to enjoy a little nature in the city. Families, runners and dog owners take full advantage of this well maintained city green space. Easily accessible & fountains conveniently located are a nice touch. Highly recommend this little walkway to relax and decompress.
Check out the artwork around the Eglinton underpass (near Chaplin)
